page.title: List of memorials to the Grand Army of the Republic

revision.comment: Link to DAB page repaired
revision.text:
[[File:Grand Army of the Republic Memorial - Washington, D.C..JPG|thumb|The [[Stephenson Grand Army of the Republic Memorial]] in Washington, D.C.]] (see also [[List of Union Civil War monuments and memorials]]) This is a '''list of memorials to the [[Grand Army of the Republic]]'''. Memorials include a commemorative postage stamp, a U.S. highway, and physical memorials in numerous communities throughout the United States: ==National== * [[U.S. Route 6]] is known as the Grand Army of the Republic Highway for its entire length.{{cite web |author=Richard F. Weingroff |url=http://www.fhwa.dot.gov/infrastructure/us6.cfm |title=U.S. 6-The Grand Army of the Republic Highway |date=July 27, 2009 |accessdate=2011-02-14 |publisher=[[Federal Highway Administration]]}} * At the final encampment in 1949, the [[United States Post Office Department|Post Office Department]] issued a three-cent [[Commemoration of the American Civil War on postage stamps#Common soldiers|commemorative postage stamp]].A. {{cite web |title=Remembering the Grand Army of the Republic Fifty Years Later |publisher=Sons of Union Veterans of the Civil War |url=http://suvcw.org/gar50.htm |first=Gary |last=Gibson |year=1999 |accessdate=2011-03-02}}
B. {{cite web |title=G.A.R. Issue |url=http://arago.si.edu/index.asp?con=1&cmd=1&mode=1&tid=2028825 |publisher=[[National Postal Museum]] |accessdate=Jan 11, 2014}} Two years later, it printed a virtually identical stamp for the final reunion of the [[United Confederate Veterans]].{{cite web|url=http://www.stampscatalog.info/2008/10/us-stamps-1951.html |title=U.S. Stamps 1951 |publisher=stampscatalog.info |accessdate=2011-03-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303230635/http://www.stampscatalog.info/2008/10/us-stamps-1951.html |archivedate=2011-03-03 |df= }} ==State== ===California=== * [[Modesto, California]]: Memorial lot in Modesto Pioneer Cemetery contains 36 graves, a wooden cenotaph and two cannons were erected as a monument in 1907. The wooden cenotaph was replaced with a granite obelisk in 1924.{{cite web |title=Grand Army of the Republic |url=http://www.hmdb.org/Marker.asp?Marker=19455 |publisher=The Historical Marker Database |date=29 May 2009 |accessdate=2011-12-20}} * [[Oakland, California]]: GAR plot and monument dedicated in 1893 in [[Mountain View Cemetery (Oakland, California)|Mountain View Cemetery]], 5000 Piedmont Avenue.{{cite web |title=GAR Plot |url=http://www.oaklandhistory.com/files/gar.html |publisher=Mountain View Cemetery |accessdate=2011-12-20}} * [[Sacramento, California]]: GAR memorial and many grave sites in the [[Sacramento Historic City Cemetery]] (aka Old City Cemetery).{{cite web |url=http://www.oldcitycemetery.com/selftour.htm |title=Sacramento Historic City Cemetery Self-Guided Tour |publisher=OldCityCemetery.com |year=2005 |accessdate=2011-03-02}} [[File:Grand Army of the Republic issue 1948 3c.JPG|right|thumb|G.A.R. Commemorative issue of 1948]] * [[San Jose, California]]: GAR lot in [[Oak Hill Memorial Park|Oak Hill Cemetery]].{{cite web |title=Events |date= |publisher=United Veterans Council of Santa Clara County |url=http://www.uvcscc.org/events.html |accessdate=2011-06-01}} ===Connecticut=== * [[Rockville, Connecticut]]: The [[New England Civil War Museum]] is maintained by Alden Skinner Camp 45 [[Sons of Union Veterans of the Civil War]]. The museum is within Memorial Hall, which was dedicated to the GAR veterans by the former city of Rockville.{{cite web |url=http://www.newenglandcivilwarmuseum.com/ |title=New England Civil War Museum |date=4 December 2010 |accessdate=2011-03-02 |publisher=NewEnglandCivilWarMuseum.com}} ===District of Columbia=== * [[Washington, D.C.]]: A [[Stephenson Grand Army of the Republic Memorial|memorial honoring founder Benjamin F. Stephenson, M.D.]], stands near the [[National Archives Building]] and the [[United States Navy Memorial|Navy Memorial]] ({{coord|38.893565|-77.021558|region:US-DC_type:landmark_scale:2000_source:Hybrid}}Hybrid satellite image/street map of Stephenson GAR Memorial in Washington, D.C., from [http://wikimapia.org/#y=38893565&x=-77021558&z=17&l=0&m=h&v=2 WikiMapia]{{cite web |title= Stephenson Grand Army of the Republic Memorial |url=http://www.dcmemorials.com/index_indiv0000550.htm |publisher=dcmemorials.com |year=2006 |accessdate=2007-05-04}}). The GAR Memorial Foundation erected the monument using funds [[appropriation (law)|appropriated]] by the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] in 1907 and dedicated the work in 1909.{{cite web|title=Stephenson Grand Army of the Republic Memorial |url=http://siris-artinventories.si.edu/ipac20/ipac.jsp?session=G1I98048Q3397.39158&menu=search&aspect=Keyword&npp=50&ipp=20&spp=20&profile=ariall&ri=&term=&index=.GW&aspect=Keyword&term=&index=.AW&term=&index=.TW&term=&index=.SW&term=&index=.FW&term=&index=.OW&term=76009984&index=.NW&x=9&y=10#focus |publisher=[[Smithsonian American Art Museum]], Art Inventories Catalog |accessdate=2007-05-04}} ===Illinois=== [[File:Chicago Cultural Center.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Chicago Cultural Center]] (1893), built on land donated by the GAR, maintains a memorial hall to the Grand Army]] * [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]]: ** GAR memorial and several gravesites in [[Union Ridge, Chicago|Union Ridge Cemetery]] in the [[Norwood Park, Chicago|Norwood Park]] neighborhood.{{cite web |title=Union Ridge Cemetery |url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=cr&CRid=108659 |date=5 July 2010 |publisher=Find A Grave |accessdate=2011-06-01}} ** The current [[Chicago Cultural Center]] was formerly the dual-purposed [[Chicago Public Library]] and GAR Meeting Hall. Completed in 1897, it occupies property on Michigan Avenue at Randolph Street donated by the GAR.{{cite web |url=http://www.explorechicago.org/city/en/supporting_narrative/attractions/dca_tourism/Chicago_Cultural_Center/History/palace_2.html |title=The People's Palace: The Story of the Chicago Cultural Center |year=1999 |accessdate=2011-03-02 |publisher=CityofChicago.org}} ** GAR memorial and approximately 350 graves in [[Rosehill Cemetery]] ** Memorial to German soldiers of the Civil War. Almost a quarter million German Americans fought for the Union, the largest of any ethnic group in the country. {{citation needed|date=July 2018}} [[File:GAR Monument Rosehill Cemetery.jpg|200px|thumb|right|Battery A Chicago Light Artillery Monument in Rosehill Cemetery]] * [[Decatur, Illinois]]: GAR section with approximately 570 graves and monument in Greenwood Cemetery{{cite news |title=Wet conditions fail to stop Greenwood Cemetery ceremony |first=Kenneth |last=Lowe |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_action=doc&p_docid=1377F96F8BF79170&p_docnum=6 |date=27 May 2011 |work=[[Herald & Review]] |location=Decatur |accessdate=2011-05-31}} * [[Hoopeston, Illinois]]: GAR memorial and many gravesites Floral Hill Cemetery. * [[Minier, Illinois]]: GAR monument erected in 1888 by the John Hunter GAR Post 168{{cite web |title=Civil War Monument, Minier, IL |url=http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WM4A61 |date=28 July 2008 |publisher=Waymarking.com |accessdate=2011-05-31}} * [[Murphysboro, Illinois]]: A cemetery with the graves of several GAR members who were former slaves originally from Tennessee is southwest of the town. * [[Palatine Township, Cook County, Illinois|Palatine Township, Illinois]]: re-dedicated the Grand Army Memorial Plot at Hillside Cemetery on August 16, 2015.{{cite journal| title=GAR Dedication Ceremony to Include Civil War Re-Enactors, Historic Canon Firing at Hillside Cemetery| url=http://patch.com/illinois/palatine/gar-dedication-ceremony-include-civil-war-re-enactors-historic-canon-firing-hillside-cemetery| work=Palatine Patch| date=July 9, 2015| accessdate=2015-08-20}} * [[River Forest, Illinois]]: Grand Army of the Republic Memorial Woods which is part of the Forest Preserves of Cook County. * [[Springfield, Illinois]]: ** Grand Army of the Republic Memorial Museum, located at 629 South 7th Street, is owned and maintained by the [[Woman's Relief Corps]] Auxiliary to the Grand Army of the Republic.{{cite web |title=National Headquarters GAR Museum |url=http://suvcw.org/WRC/garmuseum.htm |accessdate=2011-03-03}} ** The [[Daughters of Union Veterans of the Civil War]] donated a sundial that was dedicated on the grounds of the [[Illinois State Capitol]] September 8, 1940, during the 74th Encampment of the GAR.{{cite web|publisher=Illinois Secretary of State |title=Illinois State Capitol-A Walking Tour |date=May 2001 |accessdate=2011-02-14 |url=http://www.cyberdriveillinois.com/publications/pdf_publications/walking_capitol_tour.pdf}} * [[Watseka, Illinois]]: GAR Cemetery, established for the Williams Post 25, has a memorial and statue as prominent features at the entrance.{{cite web |title=GAR Cemetery |publisher=[[Find A Grave]] |url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=cr&GRid=8114540&CRid=200673& |accessdate=2011-05-31}} ===Indiana=== * [[Valparaiso, Indiana]]: The Memorial Opera House was constructed by the local GAR chapter in 1893.{{cite web |title=A Brief History of the Memorial Opera House |publisher=Valparaiso Memorial Opera House |accessdate=2011-02-14 |url=http://www.mohlive.com/about.htm}} * [[Des Moines, Iowa]]: In 1922, a banner created for the GAR encampment was declared a permanent memorial and suspended in the rotunda of the [[Iowa State Capitol]].{{cite web |publisher=Iowa Legislature |title=The Capitol Today-Third Floor |url=http://www.legis.state.ia.us/Pubinfo/Tour/vt/third.htm |accessdate=2011-02-14}} A sundial was dedicated to the GAR on grounds of the Iowa State Capitol during the 1938 encampment.{{cite web |publisher=State of Iowa |title=Iowa Profile |url=http://publications.iowa.gov/135/1/profile/8-5.html |accessdate=2011-02-14}} === Iowa === *[[Eldora, Iowa]]: GAR memorial of a metal soldier atop a granite base costing $3,000 was erected in 1885 in the center of the town square. It was relocated on the site in 1890 to accommodate construction of the courthouse. It has since been relocated to a site east of the courthouse and restored in 1985.{{cite web| title=History: The Civil War Monument| url=http://www.co.hardin.ia.us/pages/HistoryPt3| publisher=Hardin County, Iowa| accessdate=2015-07-31| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150914211300/http://www.co.hardin.ia.us/pages/HistoryPt3| archivedate=2015-09-14| df=}} * [[Red Oak, Iowa]]: GAR memorial of a bronze soldier atop a granite base was dedicated in 1907 near grave sites in Evergreen Cemetery.{{cite web |title=Montgomery County: Red Oak |url=http://www.iowacivilwarmonuments.com/cgi-bin/gaarddetails.pl?1210274838~2 |publisher=IowaCivilWarMonuments.com |date=30 November 2007 |accessdate=2011-03-03}} * [[Mount Pleasant, Iowa|Mt. Pleasant]], [[Iowa]]: GAR monument and grave sites in the pioneer Hickory Grove Cemetery, junction of Hwy 218 & 185th St.{{cite web |title=Henry County-Mt. Pleasant |url=http://www.iowacivilwarmonuments.com/cgi-bin/gaarddetails.pl?1275513496~2 |publisher=IowaCivilWarMonuments.com |date=30 May 2010 |accessdate=2011-03-03}} * [[Redfield, Iowa]]: The Marshall GAR Hall was restored in 2008 and houses a small museum.{{cite web |title=Dallas County-Redfield |url=http://www.iowacivilwarmonuments.com/cgi-bin/gaarddetails.pl?1210274737~3 |publisher=IowaCivilWarMonuments.com |date=25 May 2008 |accessdate=2011-03-03}} * [[Waterloo, Iowa]]: The Grand Army of the Republic meeting hall has been restored and is operated as a meeting hall and museum by the City of Waterloo. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1988.{{cite web |publisher=Cedarnet.org |url=http://www.cedarnet.org/tour/sites/075-bhcmemorialhall.html |title=Black Hawk County Memorial Hall |date=June 23, 2004 |accessdate=2011-02-24}}{{cite web |publisher=National Park Service |title=Black Hawk County Soldiers Memorial Hall |url=http://nrhp.focus.nps.gov/natregsearchresult.do?fullresult=true&recordid=1 |accessdate=2011-02-24}} === Kansas === * [[Baxter Springs, Kansas]]: GAR monument and 163 gravesites in the Baxter Springs City Cemetery{{cite web |title=Baxter Springs City Cemetery Soldiers' Lot |publisher=cem.va.gov |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=2011-03-02|url=http://www.cem.va.gov/cems/lots/baxtersprings.asp}} * [[Topeka, Kansas]]: The GAR Memorial Hall at 120 SW 10th Avenue was dedicated May 27, 1914, housed the Kansas State Historical Society until 1995 when the society moved to larger quarters. After restoration, the structure became home to the Attorney General and Secretary of State offices in 2000.{{cite press release |title=Schmidt, Kobach to commemorate Memorial Hall Anniversary |url=http://ag.ks.gov/search-results-detail/2011/10/12/schmidt-kobach-to-commemorate-memorial-hall-anniversary |publisher=Kansas Attorney General |date=12 October 2011 |accessdate=2012-03-08}} === Kentucky === * [[Covington, Kentucky]]: [[GAR Monument in Covington|GAR Monument]] in the [[Linden Grove Cemetery]] erected in 1929.{{cite web |title=National Register of Historic Places Registration Form |url=http://www.kentonlibrary.org/genealogy/register/GARmonument.pdf |publisher=Kenton County Public Library |date=17 July 1997 |accessdate=2011-12-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120127083353/http://www.kentonlibrary.org/genealogy/register/GARmonument.pdf |archivedate=27 January 2012 |df= }} === Louisiana === * [[Chalmette, Louisiana|Chalmette]], [[Louisiana]]: [[Chalmette National Cemetery]] in [[Jean Lafitte National Historical Park and Preserve]] contains a monument and the graves of approximately 12,000 Union Soldiers from the Civil War{{cite web |title=Chalmette National Cemetery |url=http://www.civilwarhome.com/chalmla.htm |publisher=Civilwarhome.com |accessdate=2011-02-14}} === Maryland === * [[Baltimore]], [[Maryland]]: A sundial at Warren Avenue and Henry Street in the [[Federal Hill, Baltimore|Federal Hill]] neighborhood was dedicated in 1933.{{cite web |title=Our Fathers Saved Sundial |publisher=Monument City Blog |date=June 16, 2009 |accessdate=2011-02-14 |url=http://monumentcity.net/2009/06/16/our-fathers-saved-sundial-federal-hill/}} * Baltimore, Multiple Union veterans monuments are located in Loudon Park National Cemetery on Frederick Road in Irvington. * Winfield, Carroll County - Monument to Pickett Post, G.A.R. in Ebenezer United Methodist Church Cemetery, on Woodbine Road. * Hagerstown: Memorial Speaker's Rostrum dedicated to the MG Jesse L. Reno Post, #4 of Hagerstown, constructed in 1924. Located in Rose Hill Cemetery * Hagerstown: Monument dedicated to Lyon Post #31 of Hagerstown (an African-American post), constructed in 2013. Located adjacent to the Reno Post Memorial in Rose Hill Cemetery. * Lansdowne, Baltimore County - Memorial Church dedicated to the memory of the Grand Army of the Republic. === Massachusetts === *[[Grand Army of the Republic Hall (Lynn, Massachusetts)|Lynn, Massachusetts: Grand Army of the Republic Hall and Museum]] * [[Rockland, Massachusetts]]: Hartstuff Post 74 was dedicated January 30, 1900. Portions of the wooden structure were restored between 1990 and 1999 and the structure is currently home of the Sons of Union Veterans of the Civil War Camp 50.{{cite web |title=Hartsuff Post 74 Grand Army of the Republic Hall |url=http://rocklandgarhall.freeservers.com/index.htm |date=18 December 1998 |publisher=Rockland GAR Hall |accessdate=2012-03-08}} === Michigan === * [[Algonac, Michigan]]: Bronze statue of a soldier on a granite base was erected in 1905 in Boardwalk Park on St. Clair River Drive.{{cite web |title=Grand Army of the Republic Monument, Algonac, Michigan |url=http://www.michiganinthewar.org/mem.htm |publisher=Department of Michigan-Sons of Union Veterans of the Civil War |date=19 March 2006 |accessdate=2011-12-20}} * [[Bay City, Michigan]]: ** A monument of Whitney granite on a base of the same was erected in 1893 in Pine Ridge Cemetery in a section dedicated as Soldier's Rest. Pine Ridge Cemetery is located on the SE corner of Tuscola and Ridge Rd{{cite web |title=The Soldier's Monument |url=http://bay-journal.com/bay/1he/writings/places-pine-ridge-cemetery-1861.html |work=[[Bay City Tribune]] |date=19 August 1893 |accessdate=2014-11-20}} ** In 1902, an 8-inch Howitzer siege gun cannon was added to the Soldier's Rest section of Pine Ridge to guard the soldiers.{{cite web |title=Now Guards the Soldier's Rest |url=http://bay-journal.com/bay/1he/writings/places-pine-ridge-cemetery-1861.html |work=Bay City Tribune |date=9 March 1902 |accessdate=2014-11-20}} * [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]]: [[Grand Army of the Republic Building (Detroit)|Grand Army of the Republic Building]] was completed in 1890 as a meeting place for the local chapter of the GAR. When membership dwindled in the 1930s, the group deeded the property to the City of Detroit who paid a portion of the construction costs. The building was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1986 and was vacant for many years.{{cite web |title=The Grand Army of the Republic |url=http://apps.detnews.com/apps/history/index.php?id=66 |date=January 28, 1997 |accessdate=2010-10-15 |work=[[The Detroit News]] |first=Jenny |last=Nolan |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120701130630/http://apps.detnews.com/apps/history/index.php?id=66 |archivedate=July 1, 2012 |df= }} In November 2011, the software company Mindfield acquired the building and, through the summer of 2013, spent over $1,000,000 on restoration.{{cite news |work=[[Detroit Free Press]] |title=A preservation battle worth fighting |url=http://www.freep.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=2013307050024 |first=Dan |last=Austin |page=11A |date=July 5, 2013 |accessdate=2013-07-05}} In addition to Mindfield, the building now houses an upscale restaurant.{{cite news| title=G.A.R. Building's Republic restaurant to open next week| url=http://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/dining/sylvia-rector/2015/02/11/republic-restaurant-opening-next-week/23241315/| work=Detroit Free Press| first=Sylvia| last=Rector| page=D1| date=February 12, 2015}} * [[Flint, Michigan]]: Two [[Parrott rifles]] occupy the lawn of the [[Genesee County, Michigan|Genesee County]] Courthouse. In 2003, the Governor Henry H. Crapo Camp of SUVCW restored the bases and held a re-dedication ceremony.{{cite web |title=Monuments & Memorials |url=http://www.govcrapocamp145.org/monuments.php |publisher=Governor Henry H. Crapo Camp No. 145 |accessdate=2014-05-07}} * [[Grand Rapids, Michigan]] ** A zinc fountain depicting a soldier at parade rest atop a carved column was dedicated in 1885 at the intersection of Fulton, Monroe and Division. It was restored and rededicated in October 2003.{{cite web |title=Civil War Monument |url=http://www.historygrandrapids.org/photo/780/civil-war-monument |publisher=Grand Rapids Historical Commission |accessdate=2014-02-26}} ** Oak Hill Cemetery at 1100 Eastern Avenue, SE contains an obelisk and the graves of several members of the Custer Post No. 5.{{cite web |title=Custer Post Cenotaph and Burial Area |url=http://roadsandriders.com/memorials/MI/CusterGAR.html |publisher=National Motorcycle Tour |accessdate=2014-05-07}} === Minnesota === * [[Bemidji, Minnesota]]: GAR memorial in Greenwood Cemetery.{{cite news |title=Service of remembrance held at Greenwood Cemetery |first=Molly |last=Miron |url=http://www.bemidjipioneer.com/event/article/id/100028862/ |work=Bemidji Pioneer |publisher=bemidjipioneer.com |date=31 May 2011 |accessdate=2011-05-31}} [[File:GrandArmyOfTheRepublic-MemorialOperaHouse-1898.jpg|thumb|Grand Army of the Republic Memorial Opera House, [[Valparaiso, Indiana]]. c. 1898]] * [[Detroit Lakes, Minnesota]]: GAR Park, 317 Washington Avenue. The GAR Park was rededicated on April 15, 2015.{{cite web |title=G.A.R. Park |url=http://cityweb.lakesnet.net/publicworks/parks-and-recreation/park-locations/gar-park/ |publisher=City of Detroit Lakes |accessdate=2013-03-04}} * [[Grand Meadow, Minnesota]]: GAR Hall/Museum. Booth Post No. 130 was once a meeting hall for members of the Grand Army of the Republic. The hall is believed to be one of only two remaining in Minnesota and is located on South Main Street between First Avenue SW and Second Avenue SW. The building is on the National Register of Historic Places because of its architectural and social significance.{{cite web |url=http://www.mowercountyhistory.org/garhall.html |publisher=Mower County Historical Society |date=|accessdate=2011-03-02|title=The Grand Meadow GAR Hall}} * [[Hastings, Minnesota]]: Peller Post 89 purchased one-half acre of land for a cemetery in 1905. It holds graves of Civil War and Spanish–American War veterans.{{cite web |title=Hastings Veterans Memorials |url=http://www.mdva.state.mn.us/memorials/hastings.htm |publisher=Minnesota Department of Veterans Affairs |year=2010 |accessdate=2012-02-19}} In 1998, local VFW post 1210 restored the cemetery.{{cite web |title=Goodhue County and Minnesota in the G.A.R. |url=http://privateanthony.homestead.com/Goodhue-Minnesota-in-GAR.html |publisher=private Anthony |date=9 February 2011 |accessdate=2012-02-19}} * [[Litchfield, Minnesota]]: The hall of Frank Daggett Post 35 has been preserved and houses a GAR museum. * [[St. Paul, Minnesota]]: A memorial obelisk capped by a bronze statue stands at the intersection of John Ireland Boulevard and Summit Avenue. The statue gazes toward the capitol building to the east and was erected in 1903 at a cost of $9,000. It was created by artist John K. Daniels and bears a dedication to "Josias R. King the first man to volunteer in the 1st MN infantry" and commemorates all who fought.{{cite web |title=Soldiers and Sailors Monument |url=http://www.stpaul.gov/index.aspx?NID=3175 |publisher=City of St. Paul, Minnesota |accessdate=2012-02-19}} === Missouri === * [[Carthage, Missouri]]: Park Cemetery contains a lot with several burials from the Stanton Post No. 16 with a large granite monument{{cite web |title=Park Cemetery GAR Memorial |url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=27816 |last=Onions |first=Thomas |date=21 March 2010 |publisher=Historical Marker Database |accessdate=2013-12-24}} * [[Laclede, Missouri]]: Grove and Cole Streets; Bronze soldier atop a granite base inscribed with a dedication to the Phil Kearny Post No. 19{{cite web |title=Phil Kearny Post No. 19 G.A.R. Memorial |url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=67082 |last=Fischer, Jr. |first=William |date=27 July 2013 |publisher=Historical Marker Database |accessdate=2013-12-24}} === Nebraska === * [[Omaha, Nebraska]]: [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Omaha)|Forest Lawn Memorial Park]] holds a GAR memorial and many grave sites.{{cite web |title=Forest Lawn Walking Tour |date=March 1999 |publisher=Forest Lawn Cemetery Association |url=http://www.forestlawnomaha.com/historytour.htm |accessdate=2011-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110510085727/http://www.forestlawnomaha.com/historytour.htm |archivedate=2011-05-10 |df= }} === New Hampshire === * [[Peterborough, New Hampshire]]: GAR Memorial Hall on Grove Street.{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalwarmemorialregistry.org/memorials/peterborough-g-a-r-memorial-hall/ |title=Peterborough GAR Hall |access-date=26 February 2017}} * South [[Lyndeborough, New Hampshire]]: The [[Hartshorn Memorial Cannon]] was named and dedicated by the Harvey Holt Post, Grand Army of the Republic, in 1902. The cannon was previously located outside the GAR's headquarters, [[Citizens' Hall]], before being moved to the village common in 1934.{{cite web |title=National Register of Historic Places Registration Form-Citizens Hall |publisher=National Park Service |date=9 December 1999 |accessdate=2011-03-03 |url={{NRHP url|id=99001482}}}} === New Jersey === * [[Asbury Park, New Jersey]]: Monument at Grand and Cookman Avenues erected by C.K. Hall Post 41. * [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]]: Monument at Providence and Capt. O'Donnell Parkway erected by the Joe Hooker Post 32. * [[Camden, New Jersey]]: Plot of the William B. Hatch Post 37 with monument in Evergreen Cemetery. * [[Egg Harbor City|Egg Harbor, New Jersey]]: General Stahel Post 62 plot in the Egg Harbor City Cemetery. * [[Jersey City, New Jersey]]: ** [[Bayview – New York Bay Cemetery]] — Monument and plot of Van Houten Post #3 and Ladies Relief Post #16, 44 graves including William Winterbottom, Medal of Honor recipient.{{cite web| title=Civil War Veterans Buried in G.A.R. Memorial Plot in Bayview-New York Bay Cemetery, Jersey City| url=http://www.hudsoncountynjgenealogy.org/databases/db-gar-bayview.html| publisher=The Hudson County Genealogical & Historical Society| accessdate=2015-08-03}}{{cite web |title=William Winterbottom |url=https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/7197368 |publisher=Find a Grave |date=19 February 2003 |accessdate=2012-05-29}} ** Soldiers and Sailors Monument, ''Goddess of Victory'' bronze by [[Philip Martiny]], at City Hall, 280 Grove Street{{cite web |title=Jersey City, New Jersey |url=http://ftp.genlyon.addr.com/inder.html/jersey_city3.htm |publisher=Sons of Union Veterans of the Civil War, New Jersey Department |accessdate=2012-05-29}} * [[Manchester Township, New Jersey]]: GAR memorial at Oakdale Street and Wellington Avenue.{{cite web |title=New Jersey Civil War Monuments |url=http://ftp.genlyon.addr.com/inder.html/A%20monuments1.htm |date=23 June 2010 |publisher=Sons of Union Veterans of the Civil War-New Jersey |accessdate=2011-06-01}} * [[Port Norris, New Jersey]]: GAR Cemetery of the John Shinn Post 6. * [[Toms River, New Jersey]]: Monument at Wellington Avenue and Oakdale Street consisting of a small peristyle, flagpole and two cannons{{cite web |title=Grand Army Of The Republic Memorial |url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=42156 |publisher=Historical Marker Database |date=5 May 2011 |last=Intile |first=John |accessdate=2013-12-24}} * [[Washington, New Jersey]]: Inscribed windows commemorating the John F. Reynolds GAR Post 66 donated during construction of the First Methodist Episcopal Church (now The United Methodist Church in Washington) in 1896. === New York === * [[Bath, New York]] ** 40-foot high granite Preservation of the Union Monument (1892), in [[Bath National Cemetery]]. ** Memorial in Nondaga Cemetery, erected by Custer Post 81 in 1916 in observance of [[Memorial Day]].{{cite web |title=GAR Monument (photo) |url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=pis&PIcrid=65438&PIpi=19075522&PIMode=cemetery |author=Mike Foley |date=29 June 2009 |publisher=Find a Grave |accessdate=2012-11-22}} * [[Buffalo, New York]]: Soldiers and Sailors Monument dedicated in [[Lafayette Square, Buffalo|Lafayette Square]] in 1884. By 1889, the monument began to list and was reconstructed.{{cite web |title=The Soldiers & Sailors Monument in Lafayette Square |url=http://www.buffaloah.com/a/lafsq/index.html |publisher=Buffalo Architecture and History |first=Banjamin R. |last=Maryinak |year=2001 |accessdate=2011-12-20}} * [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]]: ** [[Grand Army Plaza]] in [[Brooklyn, New York|Brooklyn]] was dedicated in 1926 and forms the entrance to [[Prospect Park, Brooklyn, New York|Prospect Park]]. It contains a triumphal arch and other monuments.{{cite web |title=Grand Army Plaza |publisher=New York City Department of Parks & Recreation |accessdate=2011-01-18 |url=http://www.nycgovparks.org/parks/grandarmyplaza}} ** In [[Midtown Manhattan]], [[Grand Army Plaza (Manhattan)|Grand Army Plaza]] contains a statue of [[William Tecumseh Sherman|General Sherman]]. ** In [[Upper Manhattan]], the west flagpole on Low Plaza at the entrance of [[Low Memorial Library]] on [[Columbia University]]'s [[Morningside Heights]] campus was donated by the Lafayette Post of the Grand Army of the Republic in 1898 and bears the inscription "Love, Cherish, Defend it."{{cite web |title=War Memorial Tour of Columbia |url=http://www.warmemorial.columbia.edu/war-memorial-tour-columbia#618 |publisher=Columbia University |accessdate=2011-02-14}} (The east pole was donated by the class of 1881 on its twenty-fifth anniversary in 1906.{{cite news |work=Columbia Alumni News |volume=12 |issue=33 |page=538 |title='81 Endows University Flagstaff, to Mark Fortieth Anniversary |date=June–July 1921 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=H8_mAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA538#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=2011-02-14}}) ** [[Mount Olivet Cemetery (Queens)|Mount Olivet Cemetery]] in [[Queens]] contains the burial lot of the Robert J. Marks Post # 560 of the GAR. In the lot are the graves of 25 veterans, 17 wives and a monument.{{cite web |title=History of Mount Olivet Cemetery |publisher=MountOlivetCemeteryNYC.com |url=http://www.mountolivetcemeterynyc.com/ |accessdate=2011-04-26}} === North Dakota === * [[Devils Lake, North Dakota]]: GAR lot and monument in Devils Lake Cemetery.{{cite web |title=Grand Army of the Republic Monument |url=http://heritagerenewal.org/stone/dlgar.htm|publisher=Center for Heritage Renewal, North Dakota State University |accessdate=2011-12-20}} === Ohio === * [[Columbus, Ohio|Columbus]], [[Ohio]]: The [[Daughters of the Union]] dedicated a sundial on the grounds of the Ohio State House in 1941, the 75th anniversary of the GAR.{{cite web |publisher=State of Ohio |title=Grand Army of the Republic Sundial Lest We Forget |url=http://www.ohiostatehouse.org/Education/CapitolSquare/GrandArmyOfTheRepublicSundial.aspx |accessdate=2011-02-14}} === Oregon === * [[Portland, Oregon]]: [[Grand Army of the Republic Cemetery (Portland)|Grand Army of the Republic Cemetery]]. Salmon Brown, son of the famous abolitionist [[John Brown (abolitionist)|John Brown]] (of the song "[[John Brown's Body]]"), is buried there.{{cite web |title=Grand Army of the Republic Cemetery |publisher=oregonmetro.gov |date=January 1, 2005 |accessdate= 2011-02-15 |url=http://www.metro-region.org/index.cfm/go/by.web/id=12685}} === Pennsylvania === * [[File:GARmarker.jpg|thumb|A G.A.R. marker at [[Brush Creek Cemetery]], near [[Irwin, Pennsylvania]]]][[Carnegie, Pennsylvania]]: When the [[Andrew Carnegie]] Free Library and Music Hall was constructed in 1901, it included a room to house the Captain Thomas Espy Post Number 153 of the GAR. The room is now preserved with artifacts and records left when the last post member died in the 1930s.{{cite web|url=http://www.carnegiecarnegie.org/|title=Espy Post Collection|year=2010|publisher=Andrew Carnegie Free Library and Music Hall|accessdate=2010-09-14}} * [[Philadelphia]], [[Pennsylvania]]: GAR museum and library maintained by the Philadelphia Camp [[Sons of Union Veterans of the Civil War]] in the [[John Ruan House]]. The archive holds numerous GAR post records and the museum has a variety of civil war artifacts.{{cite web|url=http://garmuslib.org/|title=History of the Grand Army of the Republic Museum and Library|accessdate=2011-02-15}} * [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]]: [[Soldiers and Sailors National Military Museum and Memorial|Soldiers & Sailors Hall]] dedicated in 1910 as a GAR memorial.{{cite news|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/regionstate/20010813soldiersandsailors0813p4.asp|title=Soldiers & Sailors hall winning war on neglect|last=Ackerman|first=Jan|date=13 August 2001|work=[[Pittsburgh Post-Gazette]]|accessdate=2011-06-01}} * [[Titusville, Pennsylvania]]:, The original charter and other documents from Cornelius S. Chase Post 50, including its handwritten by-laws, are on display at the Cleo J. Ross Post 368 American Legion in Titusville. * [[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania]]: [[G. A. R. Memorial Junior Senior High School]]{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/house-divided/wp/2015/05/25/how-a-pennsylvania-high-school-got-the-name-grand-army-of-the-republic/|title=How a Pennsylvania high school got the name Grand Army of the Republic|last=Wheeler|first=Linda|date=2015-05-25|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-10-18|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}} === Tennessee === * [[Cleveland, Tennessee|Cleveland]], [[Tennessee]]: The GAR Monument at Fort Hill Cemetery is only one of three GAR memorials in Tennessee.{{cite web |title=Grand Army of the Republic Monument Fort Hill Cemetery |url=http://southeasttennessee.com/www/docs/10008.3520/grundy-county-civil-war-sites.html |publisher=Southeast Tennessee Tourism Association |accessdate=2011-12-20}} === Vermont === * [[Vermont]]: [[Vermont Route 15|State Route 15]] is known as the Grand Army of the Republic Highway.{{cite web |title=Vermont Named State Highways and Bridges |publisher=Vermont Board of Libraries |date=April 28, 2008 |accessdate=2011-03-03 |url=http://libraries.vermont.gov/sites/libraries/files/bol/namedhighwaysbridges.pdf}} * [[Rutland (city), Vermont|Rutland, Vermont]]: Memorial Hall dedicated in 1899, served as the library until the 1930s{{cite web |title=History |publisher=Rutland Free Library |url=http://rutlandfree.org/history/ |year=2010 |accessdate=2011-02-15}} * Port Orchard, Washington: Sedgwick road, Sedgwick Cemetery and Sedgwick Junior High were all named after Ladies of G.A.R. General John Sedgwick Circle of Harper and Colby founded the cemetery. This cemetery was named in honor of General John Sedgwick, a Civil War Officer. In the year 1905, a group of women, wives, daughters, and nieces of Civil War Veterans, organized the General Sedgwick Circle, No. 28, Ladies of the G.A.R., Women’s Auxiliary of the Grand Army of the Republic. === Washington === [[File:Seattle GAR Park 02A.jpg|thumb|Seattle GAR Park]] * [[Seattle]], [[Washington (state)|Washington]]: The city's five GAR posts established [[Grand Army of the Republic Cemetery (Seattle)|Grand Army of the Republic Cemetery]] on [[Capitol Hill, Seattle|Capitol Hill]], just north of [[Lake View Cemetery (Seattle)|Lake View Cemetery]] in 1895. In 1922, the groups ceded control to the Seattle Parks Department.{{cite web |title=GAR Cemetery Park, Seattle, Washington |url=http://www.fgar.org |publisher=The Friends of the Grand Army of the Republic Cemetery Park |accessdate=2007-05-04}} * [[Snohomish, Washington]]: GAR Morton Post 110 established Grand Army of the Republic Cemetery was established in 1889 at 8602 Riverview Road. It contains the graves of 200 Civil War veterans.{{cite web |title=Civil War Cemetery |url= http://www.cityofsnohomish.com/pages/Cemetery.htm |publisher=City of Snohomish |accessdate=2011-12-20}} On May 29, 1914, the community dedicated a monument at the northwest corner of the cemetery consisting of an obelisk and statue of a soldier on a base.{{cite news |title=Grand Army of the Republic Monument |url=http://www.snohomishthenandnow.org/2010/10/g-a-r-monument/ |work=Snohomish County Tribune |date=20 October 2010 |author=Warner |accessdate=2011-12-20}} * [[Tacoma, Washington]]: Oakwood Hill Cemetery has large section containing several hundred GAR veterans who were members of the Custer Post and their wives.{{cite web |title=Browning 004 |url=http://search.tacomapubliclibrary.org/images/dt6n.asp?un=3&pg=1&krequest=subjects+contains+Oakwood+Cemetery&stemming=&phonic=&fuzzy=&maxfiles= |publisher=[[Tacoma Public Library]] |date=31 May 1909 |author=Amzie Browning |accessdate=2013-04-25}} * [[Port Angeles, Washington]]: Memorial garden in downtown with a plaque honoring the Grand Army of the Republic.{{cite web|url=http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WMJ47Q_Civil_War_Memorial_Port_Angeles_WA|title=Civil War Memorial - Port Angeles, WA - American Civil War Monuments and Memorials on Waymarking.com|author=|date=|website=www.waymarking.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}} * [[Bellingham, Washington]]: Cornwall Park, memorial dedicated to the Grand Army of the Republic, Department of Washington and Alaska.{{cite web|url=http://www.waymarking.com/waymarks/WMNZN1_Grand_Army_of_the_Republic_Memorial_Bellingham_WA|title=Grand Army of the Republic Memorial — Bellingham, WA - American Civil War Monuments and Memorials on Waymarking.com|author=|date=|website=www.waymarking.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}} === Wisconsin === * [[Columbus, Wisconsin]]: A bronze figure of a soldier atop a square granite column was erected by the H.M. Brown Post 146 of the GAR at the intersection of West James Street (Highway 60) and Dickason Boulevard (Highway 16), adjacent to the City Hall.{{cite web |title=Grand Army of the Republic Memorial Inscription |url=http://www.hmdb.org/marker.asp?marker=28289 |publisher=The Historical Marker Database |date=7 March 2010 |accessdate=2012-03-08}} * [[Madison, Wisconsin]]: Grand Army of the Republic Conference Room at the [[Wisconsin State Capitol]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wisconsin.gov/state/capfacts/cap_3d_s.html |title=Capitol Exterior |publisher=Wisconsin.gov |accessdate=2011-03-02}} * [[Necedah, Wisconsin]]: Flagpole and inscribed tablet in Bay View Cemetery; North Main and Maple Streets{{cite web |title=Soldiers Monument |url=http://www.hmdb.org/Marker.asp?Marker=32788 |publisher=Historical Marker Database |date=8 July 2010 |accessdate=2013-12-24}} ==See also== *[[Grand Army of the Republic Hall (disambiguation)]] ==References== {{Reflist|3}} {{American Civil War}} [[Category:American Civil War military monuments and memorials| Grand Army]] [[Category:Lists of monuments and memorials|Grand Army of the Republic]]

[[File:Loe de Jong - De bezetting.png|thumb|Loe de Jong (1966)]]'''Louis "Loe" de Jong''' (24 April 1914 in [[Amsterdam]] – 15 March 2005 in Amsterdam) was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] [[historian]] specialised in the [[History of the Netherlands (1939–1945)|Netherlands in World War II]] and the [[Dutch resistance]].
[[File:Media Network - A Voice from Across the Water.ogg|thumb|Interview with Loe de Jong on [[Radio Oranje]]]] The [[Masterpiece|magnum opus]] of Loe de Jong, ''Het Koninkrijk der Nederlanden in de Tweede Wereldoorlog'' ([[The Kingdom of the Netherlands During World War II]]), in fourteen volumes and 18,000 pages, is the standard reference on the history of the Netherlands during [[World War II]]. The [[Dutch Institute for War Documentation]] (NIOD) recently made an electronic edition of the entire work available for downloading from 11 December 2011, licensed under creative commons [[CC BY 3.0]].<ref name=Kingdom>{{cite web |url= http://www.niod.knaw.nl/koninkrijk/|title= The Kingdom of the Netherlands During World War II|author= Loe de Jong|date= 1969–1991|work= |publisher= NIOD|accessdate=21 December 2011}}</ref>
He has also contributed to many other histories on the [[Netherlands]] and was a speaker at [[Academic conference|symposia]] on the European [[Resistance during World War II|resistance]]. In 1988 De Jong was awarded the [[Gouden Ganzenveer]] for his contributions to Dutch written and printed culture.<ref>{{cite web |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Laureaten De Gouden Ganzenveer vanaf 1955 |work= |publisher=Stichting De Gouden Ganzenveer |year=2009 |url=http://www.goudenganzenveer.nl/laureaten.html |doi= |accessdate=2009-07-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090225223755/http://www.goudenganzenveer.nl/laureaten.html |archivedate=2009-02-25 |df= }}</ref> In 1963 he became member of the [[Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.dwc.knaw.nl/biografie/pmknaw/?pagetype=authorDetail&aId=PE00001127 |title=Louis de Jong (1914 - 2005) |publisher=Royal Netherlands Academy of Arts and Sciences |date= |accessdate=28 July 2015}}</ref>
Loe de Jong was [[Jewish]] by birth. He lost the greater part of his family, including his parents and his twin brother, during the Second World War.
He managed to escape [[The Holocaust]] by fleeing to [[England]] together with his wife when the [[Germans invaded the Netherlands]]. During this time he worked for [[Radio Oranje]] broadcasting out of [[London]] to the occupied Netherlands.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{commons category}}
==External links== *[http://morris.blogs.nytimes.com/2009/06/03/bamboozling-ourselves-part-6/ Errol Morris writes on Loue de Jong in the New York Times, June 3, 2009]

{{for|the book by István Mészáros|Marx's Theory of Alienation (book)}}[[File:Karl Marx 001.jpg|thumb|261px|19th-century German intellectual [[Karl Marx]] (1818–1883) identified and described four types of ''Entfremdung'' (social alienation) that afflict the worker under capitalism.]] {{Marxism|Sociology}} '''Karl Marx's theory of alienation''' describes the [[social alienation|estrangement]] (''Entfremdung'') of people from aspects of their ''[[Marx's theory of human nature|Gattungswesen]]'' ("species-essence") as a consequence of living in a society of stratified [[social class]]es. The alienation from the self is a consequence of being a mechanistic part of a social class, the condition of which estranges a person from their humanity. The theoretic basis of alienation within the [[capitalist mode of production (Marxist theory)|capitalist mode of production]] is that the worker invariably loses the ability to determine life and destiny when deprived of the right to think (conceive) of themselves as the director of their own actions; to determine the character of said actions; to define relationships with other people; and to own those items of value from goods and services, produced by their own labour. Although the worker is an autonomous, self-realized human being, as an economic entity this worker is directed to goals and diverted to activities that are dictated by the [[bourgeoisie]]—who own the [[means of production]]—in order to extract from the worker the maximum amount of [[surplus value]] in the course of business competition among industrialists. In the ''[[Economic and Philosophic Manuscripts of 1844]]'' (1932), [[Karl Marx]] expressed the ''Entfremdung'' theory—of estrangement from the self. Philosophically, the theory of ''Entfremdung'' relies upon ''[[The Essence of Christianity]]'' (1841) by [[Ludwig Feuerbach]] which states that the idea of a supernatural god has alienated the natural characteristics of the [[human being]]. Moreover, [[Max Stirner]] extended Feuerbach's analysis in ''[[The Ego and its Own]]'' (1845) that even the idea of "humanity" is an alienating concept for individuals to intellectually consider in its full philosophic implication. Marx and [[Friedrich Engels]] responded to these philosophic propositions in ''[[The German Ideology]]'' (1845). == Types of alienation == In a capitalist society, the worker's alienation from their humanity occurs because the worker can only express labour—a fundamental social aspect of personal individuality—through a private system of industrial production in which each worker is an instrument, a thing and not a person. In the "Comment on James Mill" (1844), Marx explained alienation thus:
Let us suppose that we had carried out production as human beings. Each of us would have, in two ways, affirmed himself, and the other person. (i) In my production I would have objectified my individuality, its specific character, and, therefore, enjoyed not only an individual manifestation of my life during the activity, but also, when looking at the object, I would have the individual pleasure of knowing my personality to be objective, visible to the senses, and, hence, a power beyond all doubt. (ii) In your enjoyment, or use, of my product I would have the direct enjoyment both of being conscious of having satisfied a human need by my work, that is, of having objectified man's essential nature, and of having thus created an object corresponding to the need of another man's essential nature [...] Our products would be so many mirrors in which we saw reflected our essential nature.Marx, Karl. "Comment on James Mill," ''Economic and Philosophical Manuscripts of 1844'': 1844.
In the ''[[Economic and Philosophic Manuscripts of 1844]]'' (1932), Marx identified four types of alienation that occur to the worker labouring under a [[capitalism|capitalist]] system of industrial production.Alienation. ''A Dictionary of Philosophy'': Revised Second Edition (1984), p. 10. === Alienation of the worker from their product === The design of the product and how it is produced are determined, not by the producers who make it (the workers), nor by the consumers of the product (the buyers), but by the [[capitalist class]] who besides accommodating the worker's manual labour also accommodate the intellectual labour of the [[engineer]] and the [[industrial designer]] who create the product in order to shape the [[Taste (sociology)|taste]] of the consumer to buy the goods and services at a price that yields a maximal [[profit (economics)|profit]]. Aside from the workers having no control over the design-and-production protocol, alienation (''Entfremdung'') broadly describes the conversion of labour (work as an activity), which is performed to generate a [[use value]] (the product), into a commodity, which—like products—can be assigned an [[exchange value]]. That is, the capitalist gains control of the manual and intellectual workers and the benefits of their labour, with a system of industrial production that converts said labour into concrete products (goods and services) that benefit the consumer. Moreover, the capitalist production system also [[Reification (Marxism)|reifies]] labour into the "concrete" concept of "work" (a job), for which the worker is paid wages—at the lowest-possible rate—that maintain a maximum rate of return on the capitalist's [[investment capital]]; this is an aspect of [[Exploitation of labour|exploitation]]. Furthermore, with such a reified system of industrial production, the profit (exchange value) generated by the sale of the goods and services (products) that could be paid to the workers is instead paid to the capitalist classes: the functional capitalist, who manages the means of production; and the [[Rentier capitalism|rentier capitalist]], who owns the means of production. [[File:PalmercarpenterA.jpg|thumb|250px|In the [[Capitalist mode of production (Marxist theory)|capitalist mode of production]], the [[manual labour]] of the employed carpenter yields wages, but not profits or losses]] [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-23805-1665, Ingenieure mit Konstruktionsplan.jpg|thumb|250px|In the capitalist mode of production, the intellectual labour of the employed engineer yields a salary, but not profits or losses]] [[File:1912 Lawrence Textile Strike 1.jpg|thumb|250px|Strikers confronted by soldiers during the 1912 [[1912 Lawrence textile strike|textile factory strike in Lawrence, Massachusetts, United States]] called when owners reduced [[wages]] after a state law reduced the work week from 56 to 54 hours]] === Alienation of the worker from the act of production === In the [[Capitalist mode of production (Marxist theory)|capitalist mode of production]], the generation of products (goods and services) is accomplished with an endless sequence of discrete, repetitive motions that offer the worker little psychological satisfaction for "a job well done". By means of [[commodification]], the [[labor power]] of the worker is reduced to wages (an exchange value); the psychological estrangement (''Entfremdung'') of the worker results from the unmediated relation between his productive labor and the wages paid to him for the labor. The worker is alienated from the means of production via two forms; wage compulsion and the imposed production content. The worker is bound to unwanted labour as a means of survival, labour is not "voluntary but coerced" (forced labor). The worker is only able to reject wage compulsion at the expense of their life and that of their family. The distribution of [[private property]] in the hands of wealth owners, combined with government enforced taxes compel workers to labor. In a capitalist world, our means of survival is based on monetary exchange, therefore we have no other choice than to sell our labour power and consequently be bound to the demands of the capitalist. The worker "[d]oes not feel content but unhappy, does not develop freely his physical and mental energy but mortifies his body and ruins his mind. The worker therefore only feels himself outside his work, and in his work feels outside himself"; "[l]abor is external to the worker" (p. 74), it is not a part of their essential being. During work, the worker is miserable, unhappy and drained of their energy, work "mortifies his body and ruins his mind". The production content, direction and form are imposed by the capitalist. The worker is being controlled and told what to do since they do not own the means of production they have no say in production, "labor is external to the worker, i.e. it does not belong to his essential being (p. 74). A person's mind should be free and conscious, instead it is controlled and directed by the capitalist, "the external character of labor for the worker appears in the fact that it is not his own but someone else's, that it does not belong to him, that in it he belongs, not to himself, but to another" (p. 74). This means he cannot freely and spontaneously create according to his own directive as labor's form and direction belong to someone else. === Alienation of the worker from their ''Gattungswesen'' (species-essence) === The ''Gattungswesen'' (species-essence), human nature of individuals is not discrete (separate and apart) from their activity as a worker and as such species-essence also comprises all of innate human potential as a person. Conceptually, in the term "species-essence" the word "species" describes the intrinsic human mental essence that is characterized by a "plurality of interests" and "psychological dynamism", whereby every individual has the desire and the tendency to engage in the many activities that promote mutual human survival and psychological well-being, by means of emotional connections with other people, with society. The psychic value of a human consists in being able to conceive (think) of the ends of their actions as purposeful ideas, which are distinct from the actions required to realize a given idea. That is, humans are able to objectify their intentions by means of an idea of themselves as "the subject" and an idea of the thing that they produce, "the object". Conversely, unlike a human being an animal does not objectify itself as "the subject" nor its products as ideas, "the object", because an animal engages in directly self-sustaining actions that have neither a future intention, nor a [[Consciousness|conscious]] intention. Whereas a person's ''Gattungswesen'' (human nature) does not exist independently of specific, historically conditioned activities, the essential nature of a human being is actualized when an individual—within their given historical circumstance—is free to subordinate their will to the internal demands they have imposed upon themselves by their imagination and not the external demands imposed upon individuals by other people. ==== Relations of production ==== Whatever the character of a person's consciousness ([[Will (philosophy)|will]] and [[imagination]]), societal existence is conditioned by their relationships with the people and things that facilitate survival, which is fundamentally dependent upon co-operation with others, thus, a person's consciousness is determined inter-subjectively (collectively), not subjectively (individually), because humans are a social animal. In the course of history, to ensure individual survival societies have organized themselves into groups who have different, basic relationships to the [[means of production]]. One societal group (class) owned and controlled the means of production while another societal class worked the means of production and in the [[relations of production]] of that ''status quo'' the goal of the owner-class was to economically benefit as much as possible from the labour of the working class. In the course of economic development when a new type of economy displaced an old type of economy—agrarian [[feudalism]] superseded by [[mercantilism]], in turn superseded by the [[Industrial revolution|Industrial Revolution]]—the rearranged economic order of the social classes favored the social class who controlled the [[Technology|technologies]] (the means of production) that made possible the change in the relations of production. Likewise, there occurred a corresponding rearrangement of the human nature (''Gattungswesen'') and the [[Value system|system of values]] of the owner-class and of the working-class, which allowed each group of people to accept and to function in the rearranged ''status quo'' of production-relations. Despite the ideological promise of industrialization—that the mechanization of industrial production would raise the mass of the workers from a brutish life of subsistence existence to honorable work—the division of labour inherent to the capitalist mode of production thwarted the human nature (''Gattungswesen'') of the worker and so rendered each individual into a mechanistic part of an industrialized system of production, from being a person capable of defining their value through direct, purposeful activity. Moreover, the near-total mechanization and automation of the industrial production system would allow the (newly) dominant [[Bourgeoisie|bourgeois]] capitalist social class to exploit the working class to the degree that the value obtained from their labour would diminish the ability of the worker to materially survive. Hence, when the proletarian working-class become a sufficiently developed political force, they will effect a revolution and re-orient the [[relations of production]] to the [[means of production]]—from a [[Capitalist mode of production (Marxist theory)|capitalist mode of production]] to a [[communist mode of production]]. In the resultant [[communist society]], the fundamental relation of the workers to the means of production would be equal and non-conflictual because there would be no artificial distinctions about the value of a worker's labour; the worker's humanity (species-essence) thus respected, men and women would not become alienated (see [[Marx's theory of human nature]]). In the communist socio-economic organization, the relations of production would operate the [[mode of production]] and employ [[From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs|each worker according to their abilities and benefit each worker according to their needs]]. Hence, each worker could direct their labour to productive work suitable to their own innate abilities, rather than be forced into a narrowly defined, [[Wage slavery|minimal-wage]] "job" meant to extract maximal profit from individual labour as determined by and dictated under the capitalist mode of production. In the classless, collectively-managed communist society, the exchange of value between the [[Reification (Marxism)|objectified]] productive labour of one worker and the consumption benefit derived from that production will not be determined by or directed to the narrow interests of a bourgeois capitalist class, but instead will be directed to meet the needs of each producer and consumer. Although production will be differentiated by the degree of each worker's abilities, the purpose of the communist system of industrial production will be determined by the collective requirements of society, not by the profit-oriented demands of a capitalist social class who live at the expense of the greater society. Under the [[collective ownership]] of the means of production, the relation of each worker to the mode of production will be identical and will assume the character that corresponds to the universal interests of the communist society. The direct distribution of the fruits of the labour of each worker to fulfill the interests of the working class—and thus to an individuals own interest and benefit—will constitute an un-alienated state of labour conditions, which restores to the worker the fullest exercise and determination of their human nature. === Alienation of the worker from other workers === Capitalism reduces the labour of the worker to a commercial [[commodity]] that can be traded in the competitive labour-market, rather than as a constructive socio-economic activity that is part of the collective common effort performed for personal survival and the betterment of society. In a capitalist economy, the businesses who own the [[means of production]] establish a competitive labour-market meant to extract from the worker as much labour (value) as possible in the form of [[capital (economics)|capital]]. The capitalist economy's arrangement of the [[relations of production]] provokes social conflict by pitting worker against worker in a competition for "higher wages", thereby alienating them from their mutual economic interests; the effect is a [[false consciousness]], which is a form of ideological control exercised by the capitalist [[bourgeoisie]] through its [[cultural hegemony]]. Furthermore, in the capitalist mode of production the philosophic collusion of [[religion]] in justifying the [[relations of production]] facilitates the realization and then worsens the alienation (''Entfremdung'') of the worker from their humanity; it is a socio-economic role independent of religion being "[[opiate of the people|the opiate of the masses]]".[http://uregina.ca/~gingrich/s3002.htm Marx on Alienation] == Philosophical significance == [[File:G.W.F. Hegel (by Sichling, after Sebbers).jpg|thumb|250px|Philosopher [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel]] (1770–1831) postulated the [[idealism]] that Marx countered with [[dialectical materialism]]]] [[File:Ludwig Andreas Feuerbach.jpg|thumb|250px|Philosopher [[Ludwig Feuerbach]] (1804–1872) analysed religion from a psychological perspective in ''The Essence of Christianity'' (1841) and according to him divinity is humanity's projection of their human nature]] === Influences: Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel and Ludwig Feuerbach === In [[Marxist theory]], ''Entfremdung'' ([[social alienation|alienation]]) is a foundational proposition about man's progress towards [[self-actualisation]]. In the ''Oxford Companion to Philosophy'' (2005), Ted Honderich described the influences of [[Georg Wilhelm Friedrich Hegel]] and [[Ludwig Feuerbach]] upon Karl Marx:
For Hegel, the unhappy consciousness is divided against itself, separated from its "essence", which it has placed in a "beyond".
As used by the philosophers Hegel and Marx, the reflexive German verbs ''entäussern'' ("to divest one's self of") and ''entfremden'' ("to become estranged") indicate that the term "alienation" denotes self-alienation: to be estranged from one's essential nature.''Langenscheidt New College Dictionary'': German–English/English–German (1973) pp. 166 and 167. Therefore, alienation is a lack of self-worth, the absence of meaning in one's life, consequent to being coerced to lead a life without opportunity for self-fulfillment, without the opportunity to become actualized, to become one's [[self]].Honderich, Ted. ''Oxford Companion to Philosophy'', Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2005. In ''[[The Phenomenology of Spirit]]'' (1807), Hegel described the stages in the development of the human ''[[Geist]]'' ("Spirit"), by which men and women progress from ignorance to knowledge, of the self and of the world. Developing Hegel's human-spirit proposition, Marx said that those poles of [[idealism]]—"spiritual ignorance" and "self-understanding"—are replaced with [[materialism|material categories]], whereby "spiritual ignorance" becomes "alienation" and "self-understanding" becomes man's realisation of his ''Gattungswesen'' (species-essence). ==== ''Entfremdung'' and the theory of history ==== {{see also|Marx's theory of history|Dialectical materialism}} In Part I: "Feuerbach – Opposition of the Materialist and Idealist Outlook" of ''[[The German Ideology]]'' (1846), Karl Marx said the following:
Things have now come to such a pass that the individuals must appropriate the existing totality of productive forces, not only to achieve self-activity, but also, merely, to safeguard their very existence.{{cite book |last=Marx|first=Karl|title=The German Ideology|date= Fall 1845 to mid-1846|chapter=Part I: Feuerbach. Opposition of the Materialist and Idealist Outlook|chapter-url=http://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1845/german-ideology/ch01d.htm}}
That humans psychologically require the life activities that lead to their [[self-actualisation]] as persons remains a consideration of secondary historical relevance because the [[capitalist mode of production (Marxist theory)|capitalist mode of production]] eventually will [[Exploitation of labour|exploit]] and impoverish the [[proletariat]] until compelling them to [[social revolution]] for survival. Yet, social alienation remains a practical concern, especially among the contemporary philosophers of [[Marxist humanism]]. In ''The Marxist-Humanist Theory of State-Capitalism'' (1992), [[Raya Dunayevskaya]] discussed and described the existence of the desire for self-activity and self-actualisation among wage-labour workers struggling to achieve the elementary goals of material life in a capitalist economy. ==== ''Entfremdung'' and social class ==== In Chapter 4 of ''[[The Holy Family (book)|The Holy Family]]'' (1845), Marx said that capitalists and proletarians are equally alienated, but that each [[social class]] experiences alienation in a different form:
The propertied class and the class of the proletariat present the same human self-estrangement. But the former class feels at ease and strengthened in this self-estrangement, it recognizes estrangement as its own power, and has in it the semblance of a human existence. The class of the proletariat feels annihilated, this means that they cease to exist in estrangement; it sees in it its own powerlessness and in the reality of an inhuman existence. It is, to use an expression of Hegel, in its abasement, the indignation at that abasement, an indignation to which it is necessarily driven by the contradiction between its human nature and its condition of life, which is the outright, resolute and comprehensive negation of that nature. Within this antithesis, the private property-owner is therefore the conservative side, and the proletarian the destructive side. From the former arises the action of preserving the antithesis, from the latter the action of annihilating it.[http://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1845/holy-family/ch04.htm Chapter 4 of ''The Holy Family'']- see under Critical Comment No. 2
== Criticism == In discussion of "random materialism" (''matérialisme aléatoire''), the French philosopher [[Louis Althusser]] criticized such a [[teleology|teleological]] (goal-oriented) interpretation of Marx's theory of alienation because it rendered the [[proletariat]] as the [[subject (philosophy)|subject]] of history; an interpretation tainted with the [[Hegelian idealism]] of the "philosophy of the subject", which he criticized as the "bourgeois ideology of philosophy" (see ''[[History and Class Consciousness]]'' [1923] by [[György Lukács]]).Alienation. ''The New Fontana Dictionary of Modern Thought'' (1999). Allan Bullock & Stephen Trombley, editors. p. 22. == See also == * [[Memes]] * [[Commodity fetishism]] * [[Marx's theory of human nature]] * Theories of [[class consciousness]] and [[Reification (Marxism)|reification]] by [[Georg Lukács]] == References == {{reflist}} == Further reading == * [http://www.marxists.org/glossary/terms/a/l.htm Alienation] entry from the Glossary of Terms of the Encyclopaedia of Marxism. * ''Alienation'' by [[Richard Schacht]] (1970). * Alienation and Fetishism, Chapter V of ''Karl Marx's Theory of History: A Defence'' by [[G.A. Cohen]] (1977). * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080508204902/http://media.pfeiffer.edu/lridener/DSS/Marx/ch6.htm Alienation: From Hegel to Marx] – Chapter 6, ''The Two Marxisms'' by Alvin W. Gouldner, New York: Oxford University Press, pp. 177–198 (1980). * [http://www.monthlyreview.org/600papp.htm Alienation in American Society] by Fritz Pappenheim in ''Monthly Review'' Volume 52, Number 2 (1964). * ''Part I: Alienation of Karl Marx'' by Allen W. Wood in the ''Arguments of the Philosophers'' series is an introductory article. * ''Alienation: Marx's Conception of Man in Capitalist Society'' by Bertell Ollman. Selected chapters are online at [http://www.nyu.edu/projects/ollman/books/a.php nyu.edu]. * ''Alienation and Techne in the Thought of Karl Marx'' by Kostas Axelos. * ''Does "Alienation" Have a Future? – Recapturing the Core of Critical Theory'' by [[Harry Dahms]] in ''The Evolution of Alienation'' (2006). * ''The Evolution of Alienation: Trauma, Promise, and the Millennium'', Lauren Langman and Devorah K. Fishman, Eds. Lanham (2006). * ''[[For Marx]]'' by [[Louis Althusser]], Verso (1965). * ''Hegel's Philosophy of Right'' and ''Hegel's Theory of the Modern State'' by [[Shlomo Avineri]]. * ''Karl Marx's Philosophy of Man'', by [[John Plamenatz]] (1975). * [http://www.marxists.org/reference/archive/feuerbach/ Ludwig Feuerbach] at [http://www.marxists.org/ marxists.org]. * ''Lukács' The Young Hegel and Origins of the Concept of Alienation'', by [[István Mészáros (professor)|István Mészáros]]. * ''Making Sense of Marx'' by [[Jon Elster]] (1994). * ''Marx and Human Nature: Refutation of a Legend'' by Norman Geras discusses alienation and the related concept of human nature. * [http://www.isj.org.uk/index.php4?id=486&issue=120 Marxism and Ethics] by Paul Blackledge in the journal of ''[[International Socialism (magazine)|International Socialism]]'' (2008). * [http://www.marxists.org/archive/meszaros/works/alien/ Marx's Theory of Alienation] by István Mészáros (1970). * ''[[Reason and Revolution: Hegel and the Rise of Social Theory]]'' by [[Herbert Marcuse]] (1941). * ''The Marxist Theory of Alienation, 2nd ed, [[Ernest Mandel]] and [[George Novack]], (1973).'' * ''Why Read Marx Today?'' by Jonathan Wolff is an introduction to the concept and types of ''Entfremdung''. == External links == * [http://www.marxists.org/archive/mandel/19xx/xx/alien.htm The Causes of Alienation] by [[Ernest Mandel]] (1970). * [http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/p02h7dlv Karl Marx on Alienation] narrated by [[Gillian Anderson]] for [[BBC Radio 4]] (19 January 2015). {{use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Marx's theory of alienation}} [[Category:Marxist theory]] [[Category:Social theories]] [[Category:Theories of history]] [[Category:Labour economics]]

{{Infobox academic | honorific_prefix = | name = Nancy Sorkin Rabinowitz | honorific_suffix = | image = Nancy Rabinowitz.jpg | caption = Nancy Sorkin Rabinowitz | birth_name = <!-- use only if different from full/othernames --> | birth_date = <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = | occupation = | period = | known_for = | title = | family = | awards = <!--notable national level awards only--> | alma_mater = [[University of Chicago]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | discipline = [[Classics]] | sub_discipline = Greek literature | workplaces = Hamilton College | notable_works = | notable_ideas = }} '''Nancy Sorkin Rabinowitz''' is a classical scholar, specialising in [[ancient Greek literature]] and [[Intersectionality|intersectional feminism]].
==Career== Sorkin Rabinowitz graduated from [[City College of New York]] and received her Ph.D. from [[University of Chicago]] for the thesis 'From force to persuasion: dragon battle imagery in Aeschylus' Oresteia' (1976).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://catalog.lib.uchicago.edu/vufind/Record/102922|title=Holdings: From force to persuasion :|website=catalog.lib.uchicago.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-03-27}}</ref> Rabinowitz joined the faculty of [[Hamilton College (New York)|Hamilton College]] in 1974, where she is Margaret Bundy Scott Professor of Comparative Literature. She is an expert on ancient Greek tragedy, feminist theory, and modern literature.
Sorkin Rabinowitz is a member of the [[Society for Classical Studies]], the [[Women's Classical Caucus]], and of Lambda (formerly the Lesbian, Gay and Bisexual Caucus of APA). She contributed to the establishment of the SCS Affiliated Group Classics and Social Justice, in which she is responsible for the Prisons action committee.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://classicalstudies.org/scs-news/write-classics-and-social-justice-scs-2017|title=Launch of the new Affiliated Group Classics and Social Justice at the SCS 2017|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> From 1995 to 2005, she was Director of the Kirkland Project for the Study of Gender, Society, and Culture, at Hamilton College.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.hamilton.edu/academics/our-faculty/directory/faculty-detail/nancy-sorkin-rabinowitz|title=Nancy Sorkin Rabinowitz|last=|first=|date=|website=www.hamilton.edu|publisher=Hamilton College|access-date=23 January 2017}}</ref> In 1993, she co-edited together with [[Amy Richlin]] one of the first volumes that discussed the importance of opening the field of [[Classics]] to the use of [[Feminist theory|Feminist Theory]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bmcr.brynmawr.edu/1994/94.01.15.html|title=Bryn Mawr Classical Review 94.01.15|last=Simon|first=Goldhill|date=|website=bmcr.brynmawr.edu|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref>
Having previously collaborated with the Medea Project: Theatre for Incarcerated Women/HIV Circle, which uses arts and education as a form of social activism,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.culturalodyssey.org/medea/aboutus/index.html|title=The Medea Project|last=|first=|date=|website=culturalodyssey.org|publisher=|access-date=23 January 2017}}</ref> she currently contributes to the Hamilton Oneida Prison Education (HOPE) project at Hamilton College, aimed at bringing classical texts and theatre beyond classroom teaching or elitist culture.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://classicsconfidential.co.uk/2013/10/16/teaching-greek-tragedy-in-prisons-with-nancy-rabinowitz-2/|title=Teaching Greek Tragedy in Prisons, with Nancy Rabinowitz|last=|first=|date=16 October 2013|website=classicsconfidential.co.uk|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> Her edited collection, ''From Abortion to Pederasty: Addressing Difficult Topics in the Classics Classroom'', coedited with Fiona McHardy, won the inaugural [[Teaching Literature Book Award]] in 2015.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://ohiostatepress.org/books/Book%20Pages/Rabinowitz%20McHardy%20Difficult.html|title=From Abortion to Pederasty: Addressing Difficult Topics in the Classics Classroom|last=Ohio State University Press|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=April 20, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.isu.edu/english/scholarships--awards/teaching-literature-book-award/teaching-literature-book-award-winners/|title=Winners|last=Teaching Literature Book Award|first=Department of English and Philosophy|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=April 20, 2017}}</ref>
== Selected bibliography == * ''Anxiety Veiled: Euripides and the Traffic in Women''. Ithaca, NY: Cornell, 1993. {{ISBN|0801428459}} (hbk.), {{ISBN|0801480914}} (pbk.). * ''Women on the Edge: Four Plays by Euripides''. Translator and editor, Euripides' Alcestis. New York: Routledge, 1999. {{ISBN|0415907748}}. * ''Greek Tragedy''. Oxford: Wiley-Blackwell, 2008. {{ISBN|1405121602}} (hbk.). '''Edited volumes''' * ''Feminist Theory and the Classics'' (co-editor with Amy Richlin). New York; London: Routledge, 1993. {{ISBN|0415906458}}(hbk.), {{ISBN|0415906466}} (pbk.). * ''Among Women: From the Homosocial to the Homoerotic in the Ancient World'' (co-editor with Lisa Auanger). Austin: University of Texas Press, 2002. Paperback edition, 2009. {{ISBN|0292771134}}. *[[File:Nancy Sorkin Rabinowitz.jpg|thumb|Nancy Sorkin Rabinowitz giving a keynote lecture at the Women's Classical Committee Annual General Meeting, 2018, held at the Institute of Classical Studies, University of London]]''Vision and Viewing in Ancient Greece'' (co-editor with Sue Blundell and Douglas Cairns). Special issue of Helios 40.1 and 2 (2013). * ''From Abortion to Pederasty: Addressing Difficult Topics in the Classics Classroom'' (co-editor with Fiona McHardy). Columbus Ohio State University Press, 2014. {{ISBN|0814293654}}. * ''Sex in Antiquity: Exploring Gender and Sexuality in the Ancient World'' (co-editor with Mark Masterson and James Robson). London; New York, NY: Routledge, 2015. {{ISBN|0415519411}}.
